title: How to convince my ten-year-old son he is not a robot - Quora

response.answer_text: It may be a better course to encourage your ten year old to play at being a robot. First, because he is “acting” which is an important knowledge skill. Second, because this specific role is the methodology through which he is filtering his knowledge and experience. Third, some children filter their experience through other role models, such as pretending to be a kitten or a dog, or a duck. When I saw this in my children and grandchildren, I began playing to be just another robot. (This has been a recorded message. I am only a robot. If you wish to speak to a person, press 1. If you wish to place an order, press 2. To reach technical support press 3. To return to the main menu press 4.  Current waiting time is  45 minutes and 13 seconds. Thank you for your cooperation.) http://www.robots.com/images/Robot-with-gun.jpg

Well your child obviously sees robots as being powerful, magical and probably more than a mere ‘human’. What he is not seeing are the things humans have that robots do not. Humans can love, they care. Robots do not. This is not a trait any child would want to surrender. Even the meanest and most violent murderer loves their mother, they will never surrender this. A child being innocent generally and just trying things out. Well he is not aware of the nature of what a robots is, that it is not aware of itself or others. But when you show him them falling over on youtube and trying walk while face down. How ‘unintelligent’ they are. And how little compassion a machine has… less than none. And of course when they are dead… when they break irreparably… well they are thrown into a skip and sent to the breakers yard! The question. “So you are a robot, that means you don’t love mommy? Robots cannot love!” At that point I believe his mind might change for he will never depart from his biology for fantasy. Even so though unless its becoming a danger to him, or you, then this fantasy like invisible friends is not a major issue. He will grow out of it. This is my take from one mother to another anyway.
